screens.title: Scene 1
screens.content: The Rooftop Reunion
Tonight’s target is the legendary Moonstone — a rare gem showcased during a high-profile gala below. The vault’s security resets every hour. The window is tight. The payout is extraordinary.
The client called in the best duo in the business. Too bad they haven’t spoken in a year.

Eva has the inside access, surveillance control, and the escape plan. Luca has the vault codes, the tools, and the nerve. Separately, they’re good. Together, they’re lethal, but only if they can get through the night without killing each other.
Neither of them has quite forgiven the other, though Luca looks like he’d love to pretend it was all a misunderstanding.
For a second, neither of them moves. Somewhere behind them, fireworks begin to crackle in the sky, timed for the gala’s grand finale. But this, right now, is their own spark waiting to detonate.
Your partner is making their choice - please, wait...
How do you react to Luca’s reappearance?

options.text: Let the past show — open the door a crack.

screens.content: Eva crosses her arms, posture rigid.
Let’s get this over with. I’ll handle the cameras, you disable the locks. No surprises.
Luca nods, all teasing gone. But there’s a flicker of disappointment — like he expected something else.
They move into position, professional but distant. Like coiled wires refusing to touch. Whatever they once had is buried deep — or at least, she’s trying to bury it.
Eva smirks, circling him slowly, the glint in her eye more guarded than amused.
Wow. Same smirk, same shoes. Tell me you at least upgraded your gear.
(chuckling) Some things never change. Like how you always show up just in time to set the place on fire.
Their energy crackles — teasing and tense, like a dance they remember but haven’t practiced in too long.
She brushes past him to examine the vent entrance. Her shoulder almost grazes his. Her perfume hits him like a memory he didn’t ask for. He doesn’t turn — but his jaw tightens.
Eva’s voice falters for just a moment, like a ghost passing through her throat.
Didn’t expect the Moonstone job to come with ghosts.
(softly) Some ghosts don’t let go.

They don’t touch, but they’re standing too close now. One step, and it wouldn’t be just memory. The tension is thick, edged with possibility — a residue of the last time they trusted each other and paid the price.
Suddenly, a faint click echoes from the far corner. A motion sensor blinks red. Without thinking, Luca grabs Eva’s arm and pulls her into the shadow of a rooftop pillar.
They freeze — pressed close, breath held. The sensor quiets. But neither moves. His hand lingers. Her eyes flick upward to meet his. Everything is loud in the silence.
She turns first, but not before he sees it in her eyes — not fear, not anger, but something dangerously close to missing him.
For a second, neither of them moves. Somewhere behind them, fireworks begin to crackle in the sky, timed for the gala’s grand finale. But this, right now, is their own spark waiting to detonate.
They move toward the maintenance hatch, slipping back into the dance of silent signals and shared danger. Trying not to remember how familiar this used to feel.

screens.title: Scene 2
screens.content: Cracking the Vault
The maintenance hatch creaks open, revealing a dim hallway lined with sensor panels and soft, mechanical hums. They slip inside like shadows, every footstep calculated.
The gala just ended — the crowd is dispersing, and most of the guards are rerouting to escort VIPs out. That gives them just enough breathing room.
(whispering) Patrols are thinning. We've got maybe two minutes before someone loops back.
They slip past the last sensor and descend a short metal staircase. At the bottom — a reinforced door. Luca overrides it in three moves.
The control room is colder than expected — sterile white light, polished floors, and a wall of active surveillance feeds showing every inch of the gala space above.

A soft pulse of green light flashes above the hallway panel — right on time. Eva’s internal timer syncs with it instantly. She’s been tracking the system’s rhythm for over a week, watching cycles in real time through a backdoor feed.
(quietly) Security cycles in ninety seconds. This exact window is the only blind spot. After that, the net resets and locks for six hours. And then it’s game over.
Then we’d better move faster.
Your partner is making their choice - please, wait...
The system’s failing, how do you show up?
Luca syncs her uplink to his, fingers flying over the interface.
(tight) Just keep your end stable. I’ll thread the overload.
He doesn’t speak again — doesn’t look at her. It’s like disabling a bomb: too many threads, too many ways it goes wrong. He works faster than she remembers. But colder too. Professional. Precise.
She exhales — not sure whether it’s relief or disappointment.
He doesn’t ask — just adjusts her wiring, reassigns two input nodes, and catches a flicker of her surprise.
(grinning faintly) You still reroute left-handed? Old habits die hard.

She rolls her eyes, but the corner of her mouth twitches. They shift into flow. Fingers brushing as they pass the tools. A glance too long. A smile too late. For the first time tonight, they’re not two operatives — they’re a team.
He connects her uplink, then hesitates.
(quiet) I should’ve told you the job was compromised. Before Marrakesh.
The screen glitches. She doesn’t look up. But her hands tremble — just once.
We’re not rewiring the past, Luca.
But she doesn’t stop. Not this time.
The final command executes — and the red motion grid flickers, then drops. They made it just before the 90-second window closed.
No alarms. No alerts. No guards. The building exhales. They just disarmed the system.
At the far end of the hall, a set of reinforced doors clicks as the vault area unlocks. A soft green light pulses — inviting them to come in.

screens.title: Scene 3
screens.content: The Moonstone
They enter the vault chamber, darker than expected. No spotlights. No case displays. Just a sleek pedestal lit from below like something sacred.
Eva steps in first, scanning for laser tripwires — but none activate. Just pressure sensors, silent alarms.
Luca follows, his gaze flicking across the polished floor and clean lines of the pedestal. His voice is low and steady.
No visual trip sensors. We might actually be ahead of schedule.
(whispering) Surveillance’s down, but this thing could still have pressure triggers. Let’s not test the fireworks.
The Moonstone gleams beneath a glass dome, pale and otherworldly. Silent alarm nodes shimmer on the perimeter, waiting to be triggered.
Luca crouches by the pedestal, scanning the seams. Eva traces the dome’s outer circuit with a tool barely larger than a pen.
(focused) Same model as the vault in Prague. Should crack clean.
(deadpan) You said that in Prague, too. We ended up in a river.
Their hands don’t touch, but they move in sync. Like a duet they never quite forgot.
A low mechanical hiss escapes as the vault system accepts Luca’s final code. The floor vibrates faintly. The dome unlocks and begins to rise, smooth and precise.
The Moonstone sits exposed, flawless, delicate, and deadly. But victory doesn’t feel clean, not with so much dirty laundry between them.
(low) You vanished after Prague. I covered your trail for days. I thought you were dead — or worse.
(quiet) I thought walking away was the only way to keep you clear. I didn’t know what else to do. (pauses) But I never forgot what we were. Or how fast I ruined it.
His voice isn’t defensive — it’s something quieter. Regret, maybe. Or longing. Eva doesn’t answer, but she doesn’t turn away either.

The vault is silent, but inside her, something is roaring. The gem glows between them like a memory neither of them can forget. Eva’s fingers hover near the gem — and closer still to his. The air between them is heavier than the vault itself.
Your partner is making their choice - please, wait...
Luca’s words bring back more than the gem. What do you do?

options.text: Pull him in — one last kiss!
Let it go — but don’t move away.

screens.content: Eva turns toward him, sharp and sudden, and grabs his collar.
Eva: (softly) It still burns.

Their lips crash together — not delicate, not polite. It’s a kiss forged in adrenaline and memory, desperate and dizzying. They press close, bodies flush, as if trying to erase the year apart in one impossible second.

Her fingers dig into his back. His left hand tightens at her waist, then his right at the nape of her neck. The scent of her skin floods him — salt, sweat, the faint trace of her perfume. Desire comes flooding in, and déjà vu hits hard.
They ache for more — for the release they once had, for the touch they still remember too well. But time is cruel. It’s slipping. Every heartbeat dares them to stay.
Her breath hitches. His lips linger, but hesitation shadows his grip. Not here. Not now. Not again.
(murmuring against her lips) Still feels like Marseille.
Then — a sound. Boots on metal. Too close.
They break apart, eyes wide. No time for words.
(grabbing the gem) Move!
Luca triggers the smoke charge. They vanish.
Eva exhales softly. She doesn't lean in — but she doesn’t pull back either. Their foreheads almost touch.
They stay there, breath mingling, hands resting side by side on the pedestal — suspended in a tension too fragile to break.
Then — footsteps. Loud and definite.
Eva grabs the gem. Luca’s hand finds hers for just a second. Then they vanish into the smoke.
Eva doesn’t turn or even flinch.  Her hand closes around the Moonstone.
(firm) That was then. This is the job.
Luca straightens, almost smiling. He respects it — even if it stings.
Behind them, metal echoes. Footsteps.
No hesitation. Eva grabs the gem. Then they vanish into the smoke.

screens.title: Scene 4
screens.content: The Getaway
Smoke floods the hallway. Shapes blur. Eva turns — but Luca isn’t behind her.
A beat of panic pulses under her skin. She freezes, torn between running and turning back.
(tense, under her breath) Luca?
Your call, partner.
Your partner is making their choice - please, wait...
The backup’s gone. The exit’s tight. What do you choose?

options.text: Let her go first — cover her from behind.
Go first — clear the path for her.
Suggest splitting up — it’s safer that way.

screens.content: Luca steps aside and gestures quickly.
Go. I’ll cover you.
Eva hesitates for just a breath, then nods and slips into the shaft. The sound of boots grows louder behind them.
(low) It’s tight — watch your gear.
Luca draws his small sidearm, steady and calm. For once, he's not the one running first.
(breathing out) Remind me never to agree to underground exits again.

He backs into the shaft after her, sliding the panel closed behind them. The space is narrow, echoing with every scrape of their movement. Dust coats their clothes. It’s like crawling through a forgotten lung of the building.

Ten meters down — and they tumble out into a dim, dust-coated supply alcove near the underground loading dock. No guards. No cameras. Just cold concrete and a rusted service ladder leading toward street level.
(relieved) Still breathing. And no one's chasing us.
(half-smiling) We actually pulled it off.
Their breaths mingle, and for one suspended beat, the world slows to match their rhythm.
When they break apart, there’s no smile. Just heat. Understanding. And the kind of calm that only comes after chaos.
They don’t wait. Luca leads the way up the rusted service ladder, pushing open a grate above. The city greets them with stillness — back alley shadows, distant streetlamps, and a cool breeze.
They step onto the empty pavement, their breaths finally steady. No alarms, no shouts, no flashing lights. Just a night, and the echo of everything they risked.
(soft) We’re out.
(quiet) And no one saw it coming.
They exchange a glance — half disbelief, half relief. They don’t smile. Not yet. But something in their shoulders loosens.
For now, they’ve won.
Luca steps to the opening, flashes a tight smile.
If there’s a trap, I’d rather it hit me.
(small scoff) Chivalry? Or guilt?
Eva follows. The shaft rattles around them. They hit the lower exit hard, stumbling into the shadows. Behind them, distant voices echo — too far, too late.
They drop into the same supply alcove — cold, dark, and empty. No sign of guards. No alarms. A service ladder leads toward the street.
(relieved) Clean exit.
(smiling) And no one’s dead. That’s new.
They climb out fast, emerging into the cool night air behind the building — no pursuit in sight.
They did it. The gem is theirs. And they’re free — for now.
Luca pauses, eyes darting to the second hallway.
They part in silence, each vanishing down separate paths — one step away from disaster.
Luca slips through an old maintenance route, ducking sensors and broken lights. Eva pushes through a ventilation crawl space that brings her behind the eastern lot.
He emerges into a narrow alley first, quiet, empty. One minute later, she appears at the corner across the street. They immediately spot each other.
No guards. No alarm. Just cold air, pounding hearts, and the weight of survival.
(breathless) You made it.
Then she nods. They turn, vanishing together down the street, like shadows slipping into freedom.
They did it. Apart, then together. Almost always too late. But not tonight.

screens.title: Scene 5
screens.content: The Drop
A nondescript gray building on the edge of the city. No signs. No guards out front. But inside, reinforced doors, coded locks, and silence that hums with secrets.
Eva and Luca step into the lobby, greeted only by the buzz of overhead lights. A tall man in a dark suit looks them over, then gives a short nod.
(flat) They’re expected. Top floor.
He presses a button, and the elevator doors slide open.
Inside the elevator, Eva and Luca stand side by side, shoulders just barely touching. Neither speaks — the moment is too dense, the memory of adrenaline and closeness still clinging to their skin.

The lift rises. The atmosphere is silent but charged. There’s no need to talk. The gem is safe. The mission’s complete. But between them, the tension hasn’t faded. It’s only shifted — from urgency to possibility.
(calmly) On time. I like that.
(eyeing the case) Let’s see if it’s as perfect as your timing.
He doesn’t offer his name — just a measured smile and an open briefcase lined with velvet.
Eva places the Moonstone inside. The client takes a moment, lifting the gem delicately from the case with gloved hands. He holds it to the light — the Moonstone glows faintly, almost ethereal.
They pull up outside her place — a quiet high-rise near the edge of the city. Unassuming. Safe. She doesn’t ask. Just unlocks the door. He follows.
Now, the elevator hums beneath their feet, carrying them upward — away from what almost was. Just hours ago, another elevator ride ended with gas, guns, and betrayal. This one? Still quiet.
Do you ever think it could’ve been different?
(turns slightly) Different how?
A life without vaults. Or regrets.
Your partner is making their choice - please, wait...
The job’s done. The night’s not. What do you do?

options.text: Ask him to get a drink, off the record.
Stop the elevator — don’t let it end!

screens.content: Then, without looking at him, she speaks — voice calm, but final.
You can come up. Shower. Tea, if you want. But that’s all this night is going to be.
Luca glances over, searching for meaning in her expression. There’s no malice there — just a quiet line drawn with care.
When the elevator doors open, she steps out and holds it open for him. He follows, but at a pace behind. The kind of distance that says he heard her. And he’ll respect it.
The mission’s over — but their story might not be. What happens next? That’s for the two of you to decide. Go ahead — discuss it in the chat.

Then she speaks — casually, but with just enough pause to mean more.Eva: (low) There’s a bar two blocks from here. Low lights, terrible jazz. But first… you might want to change. (slight smile) I think I still have one of your shirts in the closet.
Luca raises an eyebrow — just slightly — then nods, the corner of his mouth twitching with something between relief, curiosity, and hope.
I thought you burned all those.

(softly)
Not all of them.
The elevator dings. She steps out, tossing him a glance over her shoulder — not a promise, but not nothing.
The hallway lights flicker softly around them as she unlocks the door. This time, he follows without hesitation.
The mission’s over — but their story might not be. What happens next? That’s for the two of you to decide. Go ahead — discuss it in the chat.
She watches the numbers climb — 11, 12, 13 — and something in her breaks loose. The chase, the betrayal, the fire they never quite put out… it all crashes at once.
Without a word, Eva reaches out and hits the emergency stop. The lift jolts. Lights dim. Silence crashes in.
(breathless) I couldn’t wait any longer.
They move against the mirrored wall, bodies instinctively colliding just like old times. Every motion is familiar. Every sound is electric.
They stay close — breath tangled, heartbeat steady. Whatever this is… it’s not just about the past anymore.
The mission’s over — but their story is not. What happens next? That’s for the two of you to decide. Go ahead — discuss it in the chat.
